anchor.surface_text: s. 302 I.P.C. Both the accused were acquitted by the learned Sessions Judge of Bareilly. But the State took an appeal to the Allahabad High Court against the appellant only and the judgment of acquittal in his case was reversed and he was convicted under s. 302 I.P.C. and sentenced to transportation for life. Against the judgment of the High Court the appellant has brought this appeal by Special Leave.

s. 302 I.P.C. and sentenced to transportation for life. Against the judgment of the High Court the appellant has brought this appeal by Special Leave. The facts which have given rise to the appeal are that Sabir was murdered on the 11th May, 195 1, at about 6-30 p.m. The First Information Report was made by Qudrat Ullah the other accused at 6-45 p.m. the same day, i.e., within about 15 minutes of the occurrence.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: Court against the appellant only and the judgment

anchor.surface_text: this appeal by Special Leave. The facts which have given rise to the appeal are that Sabir was murdered on the 11th May, 195 1, at about 6-30 p.m. The First Information Report was made by Qudrat Ullah the other accused at 6-45 p.m. the same day, i.e., within about 15 minutes of the occurrence. The prosecution case was that there was an exchange of abuses between the deceased and the appellant near the shop of the First Informant, Qudrat Ullah.

A First Information Report is not a substantive piece of evidence and can only be used to corroborate the statement of the maker under s. 157 of the Evidence Act or to contradict it under s. 145 of that Act. -It cannot be used as evidence against the maker at the trial if he himself becomes an accused, not to corroborate or contradict other witnesses. In this case, therefore, it is not evidence.

concepts.interpretation: Not substantive evidence; usable only to corroborate or contradict the maker's statement; inadmissible against maker if accused

issues.text: Whether the First Information Report made by co-accused Qudrat Ullah is admissible as evidence against the appellant

anchor.surface_text: Qudrat Ullah picked up the knife which had been dropped by the appellant, put the deceased in a rickshaw and took him to the hospital from where he went to the Police Station and made the First Information Report. An objection has been taken to the admissibility of this report as it was made by a person who was a coaccused.

issues.text: Whether the High Court's view of the Sessions Judge's judgment was perverse and resulted in miscarriage of justice warranting reversal of acquittal

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges also came to the conclusion that the view taken by the learned trial Judge was one which no reasonable person could have taken. It was a wholly erroneous view of the evidence which has resulted in gross miscarriage of justice inasmuch as a murderer escapes punishment.

issues.text: Whether a passage in the High Court judgment indicated a wrong approach by placing burden of proof on the accused

anchor.surface_text: There is a passage in the Judgment of the High Court which appears to us to be disconsolate and indicative of a wrong approach in deciding the guilt of an accused person. Although the learned Judges recognised the principle that the onus was not on the accused, yet one of the observations is such that it comes perilously near to putting - the burden on the accused if it does not actually do so.

issues.text: Whether the maxim falsus in uno falsus in omnibus requires rejection of the entire testimony of witnesses who falsely implicated Qudrat Ullah when assessing guilt of the appellant

anchor.surface_text: it was next contended that the witnesses had falsely implicated Qudrat Ullah and because of that the Court should have rejected the testimony of these witnesses as against the appellant also. The well-known maxim falsus in uno falsus in omnibus was relied upon by the appellant. The argument raised was that because the witnesses who had -also deposed against Qudrat Ullah by saying that he had handed over the knife to the appellant had not been believed by the Courts below as against him, the High Court should not have accepted the evidence of these witnesses to convict the appellant.

issues.text: Whether the prosecution has proved the appellant's guilt under s.302 IPC beyond reasonable doubt

holdings.text: A First Information Report is not a substantive piece of evidence and can only be used to corroborate the statement of the maker under s. 157 of the Evidence Act or to contradict it under s. 145 of that Act. It cannot be used as evidence against the maker at the trial if he himself becomes an accused, not to corroborate or contradict other witnesses. In this case, therefore, it is not evidence.

anchor.surface_text: A First Information Report is not a substantive piece of evidence and can only be used to corroborate the statement of the maker under s. 157 of the Evidence Act or to contradict it under s. 145 of that Act. -It cannot be used as evidence against the maker at the trial if he himself becomes an accused, not to corroborate or contradict other witnesses. In this case, therefore, it is not evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of Evidence Act sections 157 and 145 limiting use of FIR to corroboration or contradiction of maker only.

holdings.text: The learned Judges were justified in coming to the conclusion that the view taken by the learned trial Judge was one which no reasonable person could have taken, resulting in gross miscarriage of justice.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges also came to the conclusion that the view taken by the learned trial Judge was one which no reasonable person could have taken. It was a wholly erroneous view of the evidence which has resulted in gross miscarriage of justice inasmuch as a murderer escapes punishment,.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellate court can reverse acquittal if trial court's view of evidence is perverse and unreasonable, leading to miscarriage of justice.

holdings.text: The passage in the High Court judgment is indicative of a wrong approach perilously close to placing the burden on the accused; it is the duty of the prosecution to prove the prisoner's guilt subject to any statutory exception.

anchor.surface_text: The presumption of innocence has been fully rebutted by the prosecution. The case against him does not become doubtful merely because the learned Sessions Judge said that there was a doubt about his guilt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Critique of High Court observation shifting burden; reiteration of cardinal principle of presumption of innocence and prosecution's burden.

holdings.text: The maxim falsus in uno falsus in omnibus has not received general acceptance as a rule of law; it is merely a rule of caution that testimony may be disregarded but not that it must be.

anchor.surface_text: falsus in uno falsus in omnibus was relied upon by the appellant. The argument raised was that because the witnesses who had -also deposed against Qudrat Ullah by saying that he had handed over the knife to the appellant had not been believed by the Courts below as against him, the High Court should not have accepted the evidence of these witnesses to convict the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Citing authorities like Wigmore and rejecting as mandatory rule; applies to weight of evidence, not automatic rejection.

holdings.text: Upon a review of the evidence of the prosecution witnesses we have come to the conclusion that the appellant was rightly convicted under s.302 I.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: Upon a review of the evidence of the prosecution witnesses we have come to the conclusion that the appellant was rightly convicted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Independent review of eyewitness testimony and circumstances rebuts doubt; upholds High Court's acceptance of direct evidence against appellant despite rejection as to co-accused.

precedents.cited_proposition: court cannot rely on evidence of witnesses who have given false evidence on other parts of the case
precedents.cited_holding: The defendants own evidence and that of several of his witnesses is of no use to him. He cannot contend that any court of law can place reliance on the oath of people who have admittedly given false evidence upon the other branches of the case.
